sentence: Chances are, you used a Procter & Gamble product at some point in your morning routine, whether in the shower, in the kitchen or even during your commute.
The Cincinnati-based consumer product giant makes everything from batteries to laundry detergent to toothpaste under household brand names including Bounty, Crest, Duracell, Pampers and Tide.
For investors,Procter & Gamble ( PG ) also provides a steady income stream.
P&G is a member of the elite S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats index, which is made up of companies that have raised their dividends each year for the past 25 years.
The firm has increased its payout for 58 consecutive years and has paid a dividend for 124 years.
It currently pays 64 cents per share on a quarterly basis.
That works out to an annualized yield of 3.1% vs. the S&P 500's 1.87%.
Annual earnings slipped 2 cents a share in 2012, but have otherwise grown 1% to 21% the past 20 years.
Analysts expect a 6% gain for the fiscal year ending in June and 8% in fiscal 2016.
P&G has been around since 1837 and continues to innovate and improve its product line.
Last week it unveiled its Crest Sensi-Stop Strip, which offers home treatment for people with tooth sensitivity.
One 10-minute application can provide relief for up to a month, according to the company.
QlearQuil, another new product launched this month, is an over-the-counter treatment for those suffering from occasional sinus and allergy symptoms.
The stock has traded flat to slightly higher the past five years.
It shaped a flat base right after clearing a cup with handle in late April.
But breakouts in P&G stock normally don't result in sizeable price advances.
P&G's appeal to income investors is its steady price action.
The stock climbed past an 83.08 buy point of the latest base on Aug. 21 in light volume and hasn't made much headway since.
